While I appreciate the enthusiasm, the comment section is cringey.  You take a comment in the video like "$10 billion gamble" and take it at face value, but your reactions clearly show that you guys know nothing about this as Boomers have been working on fusion reactors for over half of a century.  Why do you think that all Star Trek space ships are powered by fusion reactors where the matter/anti-matter reaction is controlled via magnetic coils?  Where do you think that idea came from?  Those Star Trek ships are doing exactly what they're describing in the video, but of course they are -- science fiction derives their ideas from actual science.  In the 1980s, the big thing was "cold fusion", which is the idea of having fusion occur at lower temperatures that we can control.  However, the only energy net-positive fusion reaction that we've ever been able to create is the hydrogen bomb, but the world is constantly working on making this a reality because the potential rewards are tremendous -- nearly unlimited with no environmental waste.

Is Fusion a viable Future? Is Fusion Clean?
In the long-term Fusion is the source of energy we need; it is a clean and powerful power. One station could light up a city for years. Fusion, however, is an extremely risky and expensive step forward to take. Fusion energy plants would cost 1 billion AUD to create even just a prototype just to see if it was viable, this sacrifice is necessary to help power the world and the rise in population. So, is Fusion the future? This report states the many reasons Fusion is the futuristic tech we need to survive.
What is Fusion? Fusion energy is in theory harnessing the power of the sun, in a nutshell Fusion a thermonuclear process which means that the ingredients for it to happen need to be extremely hot. unlike fission where one splits the atoms Fusion energy is combining Nuclei. Since Nuclei are all positively charged, they repel each other, in order to get the Nuclei to combine the Nuclei must be going extremely fast and to get them up to the necessary speed the Nuclei must be extremely hot. As the Nuclei fuse into heavier atoms, they release energy. To date there are two different types of Fusion reactors, the Magnetic Confinement Reactor, and the Inertial Confinement Reactor. Magnetic Confinement Reactors use super conducting electromagnets cooled using liquid helium. The Inertial Confinement Reactor uses high tech lasers to heat a pellet of fuel, imploding it to make it hot enough to fuse.
Fusion would be one of the cleanest sources of energy ever, due to little waste Fusion poses almost no threat to the environment and since Fusion cannot go nuclear a melt down would never be severe enough to do damage to people or the environment. However, Fusion would leak Tritium into the ocean system, Tritium is a highly radioactive toxic element that, in large amounts, could do serious damage to the environment. However, the amount of Tritium waste is so minuscule that it poses no effect to the environment. Waste isn’t the only problem with Tritium, Tritium is extremely rare and can only be found on nuclear war heads and in the atmosphere making it extremely expensive. There is a solution to this lack of Tritium, the same reaction needed can be made using Hydrogen, but not any Hydrogen can be used, it must be Hydrogen three. The problem with Hydrogen three is it is also extremely rare to find, however, the moon has a layer of Hydrogen three on it due to solar winds and storms. This means that before we can harness the power of the sun, we need to harness the power of space travel.
Fusion energy is still just an experiment and although Fusion can be created it cost more energy to create Fusion then the Fusion creates meaning that the technology needs to be improved before it is ever viable for commercial use. When and if Fusion is created it would be so efficient that tiny amounts of salt water could power cities for years with no waste, this is due to the reactors use helium or Hydrogen to power the reaction and salt water is filled with hydrogen. However, not just Hydrogen would work Hydrogen3 or Hydrogen2 also known as deuterium and tritium. These hydrogen atoms are much heavier than plane hydrogen meaning that the pressure that they can create would be higher therefore giving of more energy than just normal Hydrogen. Deuterium is a stable element and can be found in abundance in sea water, Deuterium is an isotope of hydrogen with a nucleus consisting of one proton and one neutron and has an atomic weight of 2.014. Tritium on the other hand is an unstable and rare radioactive isotope of hydrogen, its Nucleus contains one proton and two neutrons, it has an atomic mass of 3.016. Tritium is extremely hard to find on earth, there are trace amounts of it in the atmosphere, luckily, it can be made by irradiating lithium metal. Since Tritium is so rare another element is needed to for Fusion to go anywhere. This is where helium-3 comes into play. Helium-3 is an isotope of helium and is light and stable. Helium has two protons and one neutron, it is only one of two known stable elements with more protons than neutrons, it has an atomic weight of ≈3.016. unfortunately, it is also extremely uncommon on earth meaning that the moon is the most viable way to get helium 3. Over billions of years of solar wind, the moon has huge deposits of helium-3 scattered everywhere.
What are the dangers of Nuclear Fusion? It is commonly thought that Fusion would be extremely dangerous considering it is a miniature sun on earth, however, in comparison to other forms of fuel/energy it is extremely safe. If the confinement chamber for the plant failed, the plasma would expand and cool ending the process of Fusion. Tritium being highly radioactive could have severe effects on the planet however the amount of waste it produces is minuscule and would have no effect on the surrounding environment. Fusion cannot yet be weaponized meaning it could not become a bomb.
In conclusion, there are no negative effects on the environment using fusion meaning it is already superior to current fuel sources today, it cannot be turned into a bomb or melt down like nuclear fission and it would be almost limitless energy. However, Fusion is currently unknown and a big gamble, with extreme prices. The need for extremely rare resources such as tritium or hydrogen-3 means that before it could become commercially available, a moon base would be needed.

The problem is that we're skipping a step: FUSION ROCKETS.
We have fusion reactions, in H-bombs; which is an uncontained reaction.
But they're trying to go straight from uncontained reactions, to 100% contained reactions, which is nearly impossible because they don't have the technology.
The intermediate step is fusion-powered rockets, which are partially-controlled reactions.
These are important for space-travel, and also will provide technology to enable fusion reactors for energy.
Fusion powered rockets could get to the moon on in 5 hours, and to Venus or Mars in less than 3 days, or Jupter in 8 days; and Saturn in 12 days,
And at the same time,: as they learn to control these reactions, they can gain technological research to control them to the level of fusion generators.

Some points:

First of all, solar energy is not cleaner than nuclear energy. Gathering the materials required to produce solar panels and the storage for said energy, together with the upgrades our electricity grids would need to support the peak energy creation leads to a much larger carbon footprint than nuclear. The only forms of renewable energy that do not have this problem are hydro and geothermal. Hydro is honestly the best option in my opinion, but it's very damaging to the environment on a river scale. Perhaps in the future, waves can be used to generate our electricity but salt water is very taxing on mechanics. Geothermal is even more expensive than nuclear fusion since every place will require a different power station and there is only limited energy available per station. Sadly, our governments seem less and less enthouiastic about developing new forms of energy, and the likelyhood of fusion happening seems slimmer and slimmer with every recession we see in the developed world. Sure, the first plants might cost way too much to ever be viable but the same was true for nuclear fission in the beginning. The vast majority of the world wasn't worried about greenhouse gasses at all when nuclear fission was developed.

I doubt that fusion will ever be "viable" because we're all overlooking one important factor - the greed inherent in mankind. If I, tomorrow, developed a car that ran on water, and it was proven to work and was inexpensive to build (for sake of argument) I can guarantee you that there would be some reason why (a) it wouldn't be allowed to be built or (b) would be stopped/bought from me and then not produced simply because of the catastrophic effect it would have on the economy of whatever industrialized nation I wanted to produce it in. The loss of jobs, revenues, etc. would be such that the benefit would not be worth what the losses would be. That's what would stop it. Cynical? Not at all. Realistic. All of human history backs that premise much more than the "We'll all come together and learn to live in harmony and build forever power sources" ideal. There's no such thing as a perfect solution.

Tritium may not be as difficult to obtain as this video had made it out to be.  High energy neutrons from fusion reactions can hit lithium isotope “blankets” on the inside of a tokamak and breed tritium.  There’s enough of this lithium isotope (Li-6) to last about 6000 years if fusion energy was the primary source of the earth’s energy needs. Anyone interested in my source or further reading should check out Dr. Weston Stacey’s book called Fusion.

I'm doing this at Uni right now :)
So a few things, fusion is unproven, but the ITER reactor that is being built in France is a huge international project (costing more than the ISS) which should take us a huge step forward. I'm told, by my lecturers and industry experts who work at places such as the JET reactor in the UK, that fusion is no longer a scientific problem, it's down to engineering. Even though fusion has been 10 years away for 50 years, it is making progress. Even nuclear fission is cleaner than most forms of wind and solar power, but fusion is next level. Unfortunately with fusion, testing it is expensive as reactors are expensive. Virtually any other form of power generation you can test till failure (in fissions case you can even just blow up reactors and make a new one), but with fusion its millions to billions to make a test reactor, nevermind test it till failure! That's one of the main reasons progress is so slow.

Just a bit of extra info:

Fusing Hydrogen makes Helium. Fusing Helium makes Carbon. That in on itself is pretty useful, but we can fuse even further. Fusing carbon gives us neon, which is stable, so we can't go any farther, right?
WRONG!
We can fuse neon into silicon, which is a pretty important element but also really boring. If you're even hotter, though, you can fuse that into iron, which (as far as I'm concerned) can't be fused. So we could have seemingly infinite fuel, energy, and also a steady iron generator.

Well considering that there is a proposal to be able to build a fusion reactor that can have the same energy consumption and thermal output of ITER, but is 16x smaller, which means it can be built roughly 16x faster and cheaper, that should actually work. I would say it's Future, as that has never been on the table before. Also the Spark reactor being 1/2 the size of that for a proof of concept which it is estimated it would only take 20 - 30 million to make the Spark reactor because it's on the scale of test reactors we built today and the costs for that are actually pretty solid.

It will only be able to run for short periods of time because the vacuum chamber isn't big enough, but it's enough for a proof of concept. Basically this all derives from advances in super conductors which enable a doubling in field strength, and your power in a fusion reactor is area x field strength to power 4, so by doubling the field strength you can either get 16x the power with the same vacuum chamber area, or reduce the size of the vacuum chamber are by 16 times for the same amount of power.

Which improves the economy vastly, honestly I think we should just scrap ITER and put the money into one of these new full sized reactors, as we are not even halve way through building ITER, so going for this instead which should be able to be build ~16x faster would be a better option. as it would still be finished 8x faster than ITER.

I'm a little put off by how common it is in essentially every science video that brings it up, to characterize a nuclear reactor failure as "a bomb", especially when the people making these videos obviously know better. A nuclear reactor's failure runs a similar course as you mentioned for the fusion reactor, it runs away, the water boils off, and having lost the water used as a moderator, the reaction shuts down. Yes, overheated fuel can melt down and potentially escape containment, just as with the other. It does not explode. There can be explosions secondary to the meltdown, like the hydrogen gas explosions at Fukushima, or steam explosions from the rapid boil-off of water around the core. But not nuclear explosions. Anyway...point taken that it is still a messier event than a fusion reactor mishap, I just don't like re-enforcing the misconceptions people already have about nuclear power plants. Love the videos though, thanks!

Back to the first point:
Humanity has used the 'fast, easy and doomed to fail one day'-formula over and over, tending to destroy something unforeseen in the process.
Trivia; in this case the moon might crumble bit after bit from the mining, affecting the tides and all life on earth, and as humanity have to spend lots of energy on fixing the moon, at the same time as fusion power is running low (like our oil-running-low situation).
Speculation:
Since the people responsible shift the blame to "The government", "big companies" or some other valid scape goat humanity can bicker about, rather than helping with the cause to save us all, history might repeat itself. That is if we all don't die from the green house effect.

The 'doomed to fail one day'-formula has been done by many countries, many points in history and most of humanity has been warned time again by the few egg-heads who does the actual research on Tellus' climate.

Hypotheses:
If we go by renewable energy, Tellus will be habitable for a longer time.
Eventually humanity will have to leave the planet, since the sun will explode. When that time comes we will still have moon-fusion energy to move to another planet with (hopefully to a planet with another moon with fusion compatibility).

Irony:
This system of using moons for escaping certain death is a 'doomed to fail one day'-formula, since it's mining energy and not renew energy.
My conscience in this lay to rest in that our moon will be swallowed by our sun in any case, and there's nothing I can do about it.

Another point that makes fusion less dangerous compared to fission, is that in fusion, if you cut fuel supply (with such a simple thing as a *big red button*), the reaction stops quickly, whereas the fission reactors use solid and long-life bars of uranium, so even when we hit the *BRB*, the reactor stays dangerously hot for a long time, over a week in the fastest-cooling reactors...

Also, the stellarator system doesn't have a superconductive central coil, making confinement leaks much rarer. (I have to admit I prefer stallarators over tokamaks)

One of the best benefits of a Fusion Power Plant is that the only waste product is helium, specifically Helium-3 (He3).
This has 2 major benefits: since its waste is also its fuel, the waste can be used as fuel. Essentially a Fusion Power plant, Powers itself.
And Since helium-3 (He3) can be broken down into Helium-2 (He2) and “normal” Helium (He / He1), it can solve the Helium shortage. Solving the helium shortage also has many major benefits: Since helium is used in cooling large, heat generating machines, the helium shortage has limited that but Fusion will solve it. It would enable more large scale and/or heat-Generating experiments meaning more scientific research and discovery’s.
The price of Helium will go down further enhancing this effect. And finally, people can enjoy cheap helium and the experiences that come with it, meaning you can still have Helium balloons.

Sorry, but you ignore the fact that fusion actually produces radioactive material. The fusion creates neutrinos, which bounces on every shielding-layer and drops out electrons - what makes the shielding-layer itself radioactive. So you need to replace them - and have tons of radioactive material, which needs to be disposed. Nuclear fusion isn't that clean as it sounds. Even if i think it would really worth it, we first need to think about a solution for that problem. We will run into that problem sooner or later.
Also other energy-soliutions are not that clean as they meant to be. There are more species died on water-energy than on any other energy-production. Photovoltaic cells are producing tons of chemical waste, which really hurts the environment. Wind is okay so far, unless we use too much of it - wind is some kind of climate-regulator. If we took too much energy from it... Dead Valley is a nice place to show the consequences for the loss of wind.

In fact, i think there isn't a real "clean" way to take energy out of the environment. Maybe something like a dyson-sphere. But even this would hurt the environments environment. The only way to don't hurt it, is to don't use that much energy.

Hukum Penggunaan Mata Wang Bitcoin – Mufti Wilayah Persekutuan Dah Bersuara

Eza
November 16, 2018 8:41 am
249
SHARES
Facebook
WhatsApp

Photo by David McBee from Pexels
Baru-baru ini, kita semua dikejutkan dengan isu Mata Wang Digital Harapan Coin Bakal Diperkenalkan Di Malaysia? Logiknya adalah kita boleh bayar guna mata wang kripto di pejabat kerajaan dan swasta. Habis yang berlambak-lambak e-wallet yang baru dilancarkan bagai cendawan tumbuh selepas hujan pula bagaimana?

Apa kata kita dengar penjelasan daripada Mufti Wilayah Persekutuan, SS Dato’ Seri Dr. Zulkifli Bin Mohamad Al-Bakri berkenaan Hukum Penggunaan Mata Wang Bitcoin di bawah:



*Awas, penulisan ini adalah panjang, jemput baca sampai habis kalau nak tahu secara mendalam.

Tapi bagi mereka yang nak versi ringkas pula:



Berdasarkan pemerhatian terhadap amalan semasa, bitcoin lebih dilihat sebagai satu aset pelaburan, dan ia tidak menepati tujuan asal penciptaan bitcoin itu sendiri, iaitu sebagai mata wang alternatif kepada sistem mata wang fiat yang sedia ada
Hukum ini boleh berubah jika penambahbaikan dilakukan terhadap bitcoin samada dari sudut pengeluaran, pengawalan harga, sistem keselamatan di bursa dan regulasi untuk mengelakkannya daripada diekploitasi oleh pihak tidak bertanggungjawab
Bitcoin yang terdapat pada masa sekarang tidak menepati ciri-ciri mata wang yang telah ditetapkan oleh Islam, diputuskan bahawa Bitcoin mampu mengundang pelbagai kemudaratan terhadap sistem kewangan sesebuah negara. Oleh kerana itu, penggunaan Bitcoin yang ada pada masakini sebagai satu mata wang adalah dilarang bagi memelihara kemaslahatan umum.
MUKADIMAH


Isu ini telah dikemukakan oleh orang ramai ke Pejabat Mufti Wilayah Persekutuan menerusi pelbagai medium antaranya aplikasi whatsapp, Facebook, Instagram dan Twitter.

Mutakhir ini, Bitcoin yang merupakan salah satu daripada jenis mata wang kripto menjadi satu fenomena baharu yang kian mendapat perhatian di seluruh pelusuk dunia. Kemunculan mata wang seumpama ini dianggap sebagai alternatif baharu kepada mata wang sedia ada dalam urus niaga di abad ini.

Justeru, jika dilihat secara saintifik, bitcoin ini merupakan mata wang digital yang dibangunkan di alam maya dengan menggunakan perkakasan komputer sepenuhnya. Ia bukanlah bersifat fizikal seperti wang kertas yang ada pada hari ini. Keghairahan orang ramai terhadap bitcoin ini telah melonjakkan harganya ke tahap yang tinggi di mana pada awalnya ditawarkan pada harga USD65 dan kini dikatakan harganya berada pada paras USD6,281.76 bersamaan dengan RM26,340 (setakat 13 November 2018).



Baru-baru ini juga, terdapat laporan yang menyatakan sistem emel Media Prima Bhd. telah diserang oleh sekumpulan penggodam siber, dan mereka meminta sebanyak 1000 unit bitcoin sebagai bayaran untuk sistem tersebut kembali kepada sediakala.[1] Ini menunjukkan bahawa bitcoin menjadi sasaran kumpulan penjenayah memandangkan sifatnya yang lebih sukar dikesan berbanding mata wang biasa.

ISU DAN MASALAH
Pada hari ini, urus niaga di alam maya cuba diperluaskan dengan menggunakan bitcoin sebagai alat pertukaran (medium of exchange). Kewujudan sesetengah premis yang kini menggunakan bitcoin membuatkan ramai pengguna cuba mendapatkan mata wang ini meskipun ia bukanlah mata wang yang diiktiraf di kebanyakan negara di peringkat antarabangsa.

Maka berikut dikemukakan beberapa persoalan yang timbul di sebalik penggunaan mata wang ini, antaranya:

Adakah bitcoin merupakan mata wang yang sah menurut kaca mata syarak?
Adakah bitcoin boleh diperdagangkan dan digunakan dalam transaksi urus niaga?
SEJARAH MATA WANG DALAM ISLAM
Pada zaman pemerintahan Islam, semenanjung Arab pada ketika itu tidak mempunyai mata wang yang tersendiri. Pada abad ke-6 dan ke-7 masihi, orang Arab terutama yang menetap di Mekah dan Madinah telah memenuhi keperluan mereka dengan menggunakan mata wang syiling yang dikeluar dan digunakan di wilayah-wilayah Empayar Byzantine dan Empayar Sasan yang berjiran atau menggunakan mata wang peninggalan kerajaan silam.[2]

Setelah terdirinya kerajaan Islam di Madinah, penggunaan mata wang emas Byzantium, solidus dan mata wang Sasan, drachm atau kedua-duanya lebih dikenali oleh orang Arab sebagai dinar dan dirham diteruskan tanpa sebarang perubahan.[3]

Walaupun banyak usaha-usaha memajukan ekonomi umat Islam di Madinah dilakukan, namun Rasulullah SAW tidak mengubah dan mencetak mata wang baru menggantikan mata wang yang digunakan ketika itu sebaliknya Baginda menerima penggunaannya.[4]



Penggunaan mata wang sedia ada ini berterusan sepanjang pemerintahan Khalifah Abu Bakar, Umar al-Khattab, Uthman bin Affan, Ali bin Abi Talib dan Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan.[5] Perubahan yang berlaku ketika zaman pemerintahan mereka adalah sekadar menambah beberapa ungkapan pada mata wang sedia ada dan tiada usaha menempa mata wang baru dilakukan.

Pada kemuncaknya iaitu pada zaman Khalifah Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, mata wang Islam dengan jati diri Islami yang tersendiri telah dikeluarkan.[6] Perubahan yang besar meliputi tindakan menghilangkan lambang-lambang tidak Islami dan pada sesetengahnya menggantikan dengan yang lain telah dilakukan. Umpamanya, tanda salib yang terdapat pada mahkota atau topi besi maharaja Byzantium telah dibuang. Begitu juga tanda salib yang ada pada bahagian hadapan dan belakang syiling.

Selepas daripada usaha tersebut, secara ringkasnya penggunaan syiling emas dan perak sebagai mata wang umat Islam terus berlangsung sehinggalah berakhirnya kerajaan Islam di Turki.[7]

Sebagai kesimpulan, penggunaan syiling baik perak mahupun emas sebagai mata wang telah dikenali lama sebelum Islam dan tidak bermula dengan orang Islam. Selain itu, pengeluaran mata wang syiling adalah sentiasa berada pada tangan pihak yang berkuasa di setiap negara atau kawasan dan inilah yang berlaku sejak dari awal sejarah sehingga zaman moden.[8]

KONSEP MATA WANG DALAM ISLAM
Mata Wang dalam al-Quran dan al-Hadis
Pada dasarnya, konsep umum mata wang yang disebut di dalam al-Quran adalah menjurus kepada mata wang dinar dan dirham. Ini adalah kerana, ketika wahyu diturunkan kepada Rasulullah SAW, mata wang yang beredar pada masa itu hanyalah dinar dan dirham.[9]

Antara ayat yang menggambarkan unit mata wang dinar dan dirham yang pernah digunakan pada zaman awal Islam ialah:

وَمِنْ أَهْلِ الْكِتَابِ مَنْ إِن تَأْمَنْهُ بِقِنطَارٍ يُؤَدِّهِ إِلَيْكَ وَمِنْهُم مَّنْ إِن تَأْمَنْهُ بِدِينَارٍ لَّا يُؤَدِّهِ إِلَيْكَ إِلَّا مَا دُمْتَ عَلَيْهِ قَائِمًا ذَٰلِكَ بِأَنَّهُمْ قَالُوا لَيْسَ عَلَيْنَا فِي الْأُمِّيِّينَ سَبِيلٌ وَيَقُولُونَ عَلَى اللَّـهِ الْكَذِبَ وَهُمْ يَعْلَمُونَ

Maksudnya: “Dan di antara Ahli Kitab, ada orang yang kalau engkau amanahkan dia menyimpan sejumlah besar harta sekalipun, ia akan mengembalikannya (dengan sempurna) kepadamu, dan ada pula di antara mereka yang kalau engkau amanahkan menyimpan sedinar pun, ia tidak akan mengembalikannya kepadamu kecuali kalau engkau selalu menuntutnya. Yang demikian itu ialah kerana mereka mengatakan: “Tidak ada jalannya kami menanggung dosa mengenai orang-orang yang Ummi dan, mereka pula selalu berkata dusta terhadap Allah sedang mereka mengetahui (bahawa mereka adalah berdusta).”

(Surah Ali Imran: 74)

There is a minimum limit on energy produced when the fusion will start on being profitable, calleb break even point Q. When the breakeven point is achieved, the reactor can continue the fusion with the energy it has produced and thus starting to make "unlimited" energy Q >> 1, but of course there are other limiting factors. The test tokamaks have already achieved ~60% of the break in point and the I.T.E.R should achieve Q>10 when tested. So we may really not be that far now.

There is no such thing as unlimited free energy. Fission and fusion power both still use up resources, which cannot be renewed or recycled. Solar panels require some fairly rare materials, but at least the materials aren't used up and are (hypothetically) recyclable. Attempting to recycle fusion or fission products would require more energy than was produced in the first place. I mean, sure, fission /sounds/ cool, but I am unconvinced by it as a way forward.

People should start talking about THORIUM energy and make it well known! LFTR reactors are crazy amazing, clean, entirely safe, ultra efficient - and they aren't theoretical, a few have actually been made! Some were already made decades ago. Not much attention was paid to them (or other on 2nd or 3rd gen reactor designs) back then, because of the cold war (and making plutonium). Fusion is a nice dream, it seriously is, but everything we know about it strongly indicates it only happens in the most extreme places like white hot star cores hundreds of times bigger than the planet you stand on. Trying to harness fusion is very likely something that's simply not possible in any realistic way ( trust me, I'd very much like to be wrong). However, it's kind of a moot point - we have thorium! It's common! We have enough to power human's needs for hundreds of millions of years, arguably up to a billion, with almost no footprint, no long term waste, clean as a whistle, meltdown proof, and it's already a solid proven concept. People are trying to chase down the golden goose of fusion, yet we already have something just as good around (which doesn't involve mining on the moon ). Thus I strongly suggest people start spreading the word around! Sooner or later when awareness reaches the right point, building these things will become obvious and quite commonplace.

TLDR: LFTR. Thorium.

This video phrases the difference between the safety of fusion and fission poorly. It is suggested, whether intentionally or not (probably "not"), that what makes fusion plants safer than fission plants is that fusion "is not a bomb."

I think Kurzgesagt probably knows this, but Fission/current nuclear power plants do not explode when they "meltdown." This is a common myth often popularised by tv and movies. Instead, they tend more to just leak horrifically destructive waste into the surrounding area. During such an event, the surrounding population (of people, at least) can usually be evacuated before there are too many casualties. And tbh, meltdowns in modern reactors are exceptionally rare, and the technology is such that if proper procedure is followed, there should be no way for a meltdown to ever occur... in modern reactors. (repeated for emphasis)

Anyway, this is an important difference, as many people today still fear exploding as a possible outcome of living near a nuclear power plant, and the fact is that those fears are utterly groundless.

People often like to draw the comparison with fission. Fission went from a theory "this aught to work", to functioning "hey, look, we got it" in under 10 years. Power from fission has numerous flavours.

Fusion has also been theoretically understood for decades. Fusion is so easy that more than a dozen precocious highschoolers have build fusion reactors as science fair projects. But so far all fusion reactors are energy sinks. Decades of theory, hundreds of kicks at the can, close to $100 billion spent, still not breaking even.

There is a fusion reactor at the center of our solar system that outputs trillions if times more energy than our whole civilization currently uses. We know how to harvest it. It has been going steady for over 4 billion years and is expected to keep going for around 5 billion more years. Our sun is just 1 of an estimated 400 billion in our galaxy and 10^21 stars in the visible universe.

This video isn't fully accurate. Lithium actually can degenerate into deuterium and helium three in the core of a fusion reactor because the reaction causes beta radiation. One of the neutrons of the fusion reaction breaks of relative to the speed of light and hits surrounding particles. This can cause lithium to radioactively decay. This means that a stable fusion reaction only needs hydrogen as fuel and lithium present once the reaction has already started. The reason this is important is because the only way fusion reactions become viable as a source of power is to make the reaction stable. A long fusion burn makes back the energy of ignition within a few seconds of activity. So even a fusion reaction lasting 5 or so seconds should be viable as a source of fuel since you would receive double or more of the energy you put in. The biggest hurdle to fusion right now is that the longest fusion reaction was a little more than a second with most only lasting fractions of a second. That's because the fusion cores aren't big enough to feasibly feed more fuel into the reactor cell to keep the burn going. That and adding fuel is really hard to begin with since that would most likely depressurize the chamber. The are some groundbreaking theories on the topic, but this video makes fusion reactions sound like only a possibility instead of the inevitability that it actually is.

The science of fusion is the EASY part. The HARD part is the engineering. Fusion creates “fast neutrons”. (Fission creates slow neutrons). The creation of these neutrons is fundamental, can’t be changed/altered/or modified. They are essential.

So, why are fast neutrons a problem? Quite simply, if you do the calculations, in a reactor creating fusion power, the the number/density of fast neutrons will destroy the reactor within a matter of months, maybe a year! The ONLY efficient way to absorb fast neutrons is with Lithium. So a fusion reactor must be be pure lithium on its inside. Pure. It can’t be an alloy with anything. But lithium is a soft metal with a low melting point, so cannot be used to create any structure.

Fusion as science - fine.

Fusion as viable energy technology - non-sense, as soon as you look into what fast neutrons do to the reaction vessel.

If and when the first fusion reactors come onto the market, chances are they won't be able to produce anymore energy than the standard dam, coal/natural gas plant, or nuclear power station. This is because a fusion plant, unlike other forms of power plants, will be such an extremely power hungry facility in order operate. It won't produce energy so much as it will produce more energy than it consumes. It is for this reason that fusion, at least when it first comes out, probably won't replace all of our energy sources, but will instead just be an extra addition to our energy energy supply. Fusion will eventually slowly progress by increasing it's surplus bit by bit over many decades. So creating a fusion reactor that makes energy is one thing. Building one that gives you the energy releases that fusion on it's own can produce is another.

Unfortunately it's not quite true that there's no radioactive waste from fusion. The byproducts of the reaction are Helium (inert and safe) and extra neutrons. Unlike in fission, those extra neutrons are useless (though in fission you don't want all of them anyway since that's how you make a bomb), and just like in fission reactors the unneeded neutrons tend to combine with the atoms of the equipment surrounding them. Unfortunately, adding neutrons tends to make unstable, radioactive isotopes out of the equipment.
Induced radioactivity is much more short-lived (though still very long by human standards) but it's also extremely radioactive in that time. Fission reactors create this too, along with their normal radioactive waste byproducts, so it would still be quite a lot less waste than a fission reactor, but it's not free of the problem of radioactive waste.

On a different note, though there's not much Tritium on Earth due to its short half-life, it can be created by causing Lithium to split by hitting it with neutrons. Which given the neutron flux problem I mentioned makes it a pretty nice combination.

If we look at our sun's photosphere, we can spectrometrically see a lot of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium, several planetary masses of stuff per element. And if we already can measure quite high amounts of iron in the photosphere, we can assume that even more iron and other stuff occupies the small core zone, where pressure and temperature are sufficient for continuous fusion.

Even if the core would initially be free of heavier elements, the fusion process itself would contaminate the core and the sun would seize any fusion processes after a few thousand years. Like connecting the exhaust of your car to the air intake manifold, which does work, for a few seconds.

The necessary convection has been measured to be less than 1% of what'd be necessary for energy transort.
Furthermore, sunspots are dents/impressions in the photosphere, they should shine brightly, if they are just a thinner portion of an otherwise opaque medium and if any energy would be transported from the inside to the outside. They are like scratches in black paint covering a lightbulb.

Neutrinos have been pinpointed to emanate from the solar rim/surface, with concentrations on flares and CME locations and timeframes, and not from the core region.

Tokamaks, spheromaks, Stellarators, Wendelsteins and basically all reactor types based on emulating what we believe is in our sun's core will never work.

Electrodynamically initiated Z-pinch fusion as experimented on by the Sandia National Labs is more realistic.

Uhh...the Deuterium-Deuterium reaction has a lower activation energy than Deuterium-Tritium. Plus, Tritium is one of the two possible products of the D-D reaction, so if you want to use Tritium in your fusion, you can get it that way. He3 is the other possible product, so if you want that...again, use the D-D reaction to get it. Once you're there, D-T and D-He3 both make He4, which is the most common form of Helium.

So literally all you need is heavy water, an electrolysis machine, and a fusion machine that doesn't burn more energy than it makes (plus the energy needed to isolate the heavy water from the rest of the water and the energy needed to electrolyse that water to get the deuterium away from the oxygen).

A couple of safety hazards that you missed, though they're relatively easy to deal with. First off is that all of this fuel is hydrogen, which is kinda a problem if you have any fires around. See the Hindenburg for details. Second is that the fusion reactions pretty much all throw off neutron radiation, which is really scary for traditional radiation shields because it goes right through things like lead, instead latching onto light elements like hydrogen, carbon, oxygen and nitrogen. Basically stuff people are made of. However, water makes for a really effective shield because it has a lot of hydrogen and is quite dense, so you just need to make sure the fusion machine is surrounded by water. Also, even if things do go wrong in the worst possible way, both of these will tend to have very localized effects. And a side benefit of that water screen is that the neutrons latching onto hydrogen in that water are making more deuterium and occasionally tritium (it has to hit a deuterium atom for that, so less likely), which means you can have that water tank be the storage for water going through the deuterium extraction process and get better yields from it.

Great video! However, the tritium/helium-3 argument isn't quite right.
Yes, there isn’t enough naturally occurring tritium in the world for fusion at large-scales. However, a clever source of tritium is to “breed” it by bombarding lithium with neutrons. Deuterium-tritium fusion already creates neutrons, so the reactor wall will need to be lined with lithium. The newly bred tritium can then be harvested from the wall. If we can make MORE tritium than we use, voila, unlimited tritium. This is currently seen as the most viable source of tritium for fusion.

The reason for considering helium3 is different than what the video is stating. Deuterium- helium3 fusion is fundamentally different than deuterium-tritium fusion because it doesn’t create neutrons. A huge obstacle with fusion reactors is the damaging effects of neutrons hitting the reactor walls. You can’t simply use magnetic confinement to prevent the neutrons from hitting the wall. The neutron is uncharged. It’s unaffected by the magnetic field!

TLDR: the problem with tritium is not that it’s rare (we can breed it). The problem is that fusion using tritium will create neutrons, which can’t be contained, and does serious damage to the reactor walls.

I was disappointed to not see any mention of quantum tunneling in this video and why it's important to to fusion in a star vs fusion on earth.

Any fusion reaction done on earth has to be heated to temperatures greater than those inside the sun because the sun cheats the actual heat/pressure requirements for fusion by having atomic nuclei fuse through quantum tunneling. Fusion reactions on earth can't use this same mechanism because they don't have nearly as much plasma mass, and therefore not nearly the same chance of having a quantum tunneling event occur.

Once again, you need energy to produce the fuel. Since you need an unnatural mechanism to replicate the conditions of the inside of a star, you will use what you have available. Fusion!

Thermal dynamics
The law of the conservation of energy states that in an isolated system the total amount of energy remains the same.[1] Energy can neither be created nor destroyed but can be transformed into another form. This transformation is as a result of objects moving within the 4-dimensional non-Euclidean geometric area we call spacetime[2] which also confirms Newtons second law of thermal dynamics that the total entropy of an isolated system always increases with time.
Newtons first law of thermal dynamics is proof of the conservation of energy and is given by the equation:
dU = Q – W
Where “dU” represents the change of the internal energy of a system, “Q” is the heat (or energy) added to the system and “W” is the work done by the system.[3]

Germany's Wildly Complex Fusion Reactor Is Actually Working
The Wendelstein 7-X reactor, which uses a complex design called a stellerator, is performing just like it was predicted to.


By Avery Thompson
Dec 6, 2016

Last year, Germany completed and turned on the Wendelstein 7-X nuclear fusion reactor. This amazing piece of technology uses a complicated design called a stellerator, and scientists have finally managed to verify that the design works like it's supposed to.

Nuclear fusion is a reaction like a type that powers the Sun and other stars. Unlike the nuclear fission underway at our current nuclear plants, fusion generates far more energy without any harmful waste products. Theoretically, fusion reactors are capable of producing nearly limitless energy using nothing but seawater as fuel.

Wait what? Heat isn't what triggers nuclear fusion in the core of the sun, or any star as massive or less massive than it (which is the overwhelming majority of stars), quantum tunneling is. 15 million C isn't enough to overcome the repulsive force between the two positively charged particles, that takes upwards of 150 million C, which is what we run nuclear fusion reactors on Earth at.

What fuels the nuclear fusion in stars is, as mentioned, quantum tunneling. At the quantum scale, particles don't exist at fixed points in space. Due to wave-particle duality, they have an area within which there are different probabilities that they might exist. Stellar fusion takes place when one H1 nucleus, a single proton, bumps into another and at the same instant decides that the particle exists at the other side of the other particle's Coulomb barrier, traveling through it without interacting with it - quantum tunneling.

I understand that you couldn't fit an explanation of quantum mechanics into this video but saying that 14 mil C (..isn't it 15?) is hot enough for nuclear fusion and that that's what's going on in our sun is very misleading and wholly incorrect.

I read a book published in 1984 called Man Made Sun: The quest for fusion power. by T.A. Heppenheimer that was overly optimistic but full of a lot of information about the current state (1984) of research. One thing in the book struck me as being of massive importance as far as the safety of fusion reactors is concerned, and I've never seen it addressed in any other forum.

The author stated that a running fusion reactor would emit alpha particles that would energize and mechanically weaken any exposed ferrous metal used in the containment vessel. The quality and quantity of the radiation would be determined by the type of fusion reaction. Depending on the level of exposure, the containment vessel would have to have active cooling (probably liquid graphite) for its entire service life and well into its retirement. Possibly for hundreds of years! Any failure of the cooling system would result in a cloud of vapourized radioactive metal, possibly within minutes of the cooling system failure in the more extreme scenarios.

Has this problem been successfully addressed, or is it being glossed over as a "minor issue" on the way to a Glorious Future? A danger that only lasts 10 to 300 years can seem pretty minor compared to the half life of some fission waste products, but it is still capable of giving you a very bad day.

Whether it's fission or fusion, both are limited by the availability of some very
scarce elements (among others, beryllium, hafnium, niobium, yttrium, zirconium)
that are required for the containment of the reactions.
For some of those elements, world reserves will be depleted within a couple of
decades at present rates of consumption.

The onus is on those proposing new reactors to show how they will guarantee the
supply of the fuel and all other elements for the operational lifetime of the
facility.

This video got a ton of stuff wrong.

First, there are high temperature superconductors commercially available as tape that only need to be cooled to liquid Nitrogen temps. For more info, look at the SPARC project proposal from MIT. These superconductors also allow for a much higher magnetic flux, which means you can make a smaller and more economic fusion reactor.

Secondly, the fuel problem can be solved by using a lithium blanket, or a lithium based molten salt coolant. The neutrons thrown off by this reactor could hit Lithium atoms, causing them to decay to tritium and therefore providing a source of fuel. This reaction would produce more tritium than consumed, and on site; therefore tritium availability would not be a limiting factor.

Another really interesting fusion technique would be "Muon catalyzed fusion".

It explots the fact that muons are 207 times heavier than electrons , making the Deulterium-Tririum bond 207 times shorter , which is enought for allowing tunneling and therefore fusion at ambient temperature.

The probelms with this is that Muons have a fairly high probability to "stick" to the Alpha particle , therefore being lost as a catalyst , and at the moment producing Muons is far too energy expensive compared to the energy produced.
If some breakthrough gave us a couple of orders of magnitude more efficiency on either of those processes we could manage to get nuclear fusion at ambient temperature.

You completely forgot to address shielding, which is an utter game-changer for fusion as it turns fusion from being the perfect energy-solution to something that just might be a good situational idea in a few cases.

The Shielding Material gets heavily bombarded by radiation and over time radioactively activated. It degrades very quickly, needs to be replaced on a daily basis(which introduces huge complications, since the reactor should ideally keep running for really long times, turning it off on a daily basic really hurts efficiency and replacing the shielding while it is running it almost impossible.) and the old, degraded parts are highly radioactive..

So yes, a fusion reactor needs a lot of fresh material(although, it is not fuel, its just shielding) and also produces a lot of nuclear waste. It's better than nuclear fission, but not at all the praised, all-problems-solving salvation.

POSSIBLE INACCURACY: Mr. Kurzgesagt, to the best of my meager knowledge, deuterium-tritium fusion is the current direction of most fusion research, and tritium can easily be obtained by neutron irradiation of lithium-6 and lithium-7 (e.g. putting a chunk of lithium into a fission or fusion reactor). The main downside to Deuterium-Tritium reactions are the neutrons produced, which cause heavy shielding requirements and irradiate structural metals. He-3-Deuterium fusion is not under development, and the costs of extracting He-3 from lunar regolith (which is present in concentrations of 1.3-15 parts per billion according to wikipedia) would greatly outweigh the benefits - especially when you can wait 12 years for half of your tritium to decay into He-3.

I would not get too excited.  One has to wonder exactly how usable electricity is obtained from fusion.  Fusion reactions produce neutrons.  Neutron detectors are a sure fire way of knowing if your fusion reactor is working or not.  Neutrons emitted from a fusion reactor have to be slowed down and captured in a wall of lithium.  The lithium heats up, and the heat is used to generate steam.  The steam turns the turbine.  This is not very much different than how most nuclear reactors work, sans the whole meltdown scenario.  However, when neutrons collide with matter, they can turn the matter radioactive.  Thus, fusion reactors do produce nuclear waste.  Neutron collisions also degrade the materials used in the reactor, as elements within the material convert into different elements with different properties after being hit by a free neutron.

Nuclear power is a fascinating topic. The current plan with fusion power is to take deuterium from seawater and use lithium to breed tritium. Then use the deuterium and tritium in the reactor. Processing the deuterium and tritium takes far less energy than the fusion reaction can produce, making it feasable. Deuterium and helium-3, like you mentioned, are a possible method, but acquiring He-3 is very difficult. It is also possible to use only two deuteriums, but this is difficult.

Heck, even regular nuclear fission isn't as bad as people claim. Look at Fukoshima: a 40 year old plant was hit by one of the worst possible natural disasters and hasn't managed to kill anybody yet. Even the excess-cancer risks are tiny compared to natural radiation. Only 30 people (all plant workers) recieved doses large enough cause a noticeably higher likelyhood of cancer (still really low). Chernobyl was bad, but it was also easily preventable: they didn't even have a containment building (like all first-world reactors use). In the US, more people have been killed by solar power accidents than nuclear power accidents (even though nuclear power produces 40 times more energy than solar). The nice thing about the waste is that it's so small: most reactors keep the waste on sight so they can monitor it and it doesn't take up much space. That's probbaly why we haven't had any issues with storing it. Heck, if you recycle the waste (like France does), you only need to store it for about 300 years before it is safe. The exception is nuclear weapons: the waste from the production of nuclear weapons has been pretty bad (mostly because nuclear weapons were developed before we really knew what to do with the waste). But since we arent mass-producing nuclear weapons anymore, at least that isn't going to get worse.

"Stars cheat to reach these temperatures"

Well, you're not wrong. But it's actually theorised that it's not the pressure of the stars that let them fuse hydrogen. They'd still need to be far hotter than they are to reliably produce fusion energy. That's why fusion reactors on earth such as ITER have to be far hotter than the core of our own sun (which another fun fact, is among the hottest stars that we know to exist). Scientists have run the numbers and found that exactly 0% of the collisions between hydrogen atoms in the sun would have the energy required to fuse.

Except for one thing. One incredible and near incomprehensible exception. Quantum teleportation. Very rarely - but in something as massive as a star, relatively often - the particles of the hydrogen teleport into each other so that they fuse. They literally just pass an impassible barrier. It's not yet entirely understood how, but they do.

Around 3:00, the statement is made that there is no waist. This is a little misleading, and one of the big issues with fusion power (outside of getting a output / input = Q > 1) is the release of high energy neutrons. In a deuterium-tritium reaction, there's a leftover neutron which contains a significant portion of the energy released in the reaction. Because it's a neutron, there's no good way to control them. They normally end up colliding with the containment wall's atoms. These atoms absorb the neutron, thus rendering stable atoms now unstable (for most atoms).

There is talk about using Lithium in the containment, which has two stable isotopes. If the containment uses the lighter lithium, then it will just become the heavier kind after collision. However, this requires the use of massive quantities of lithium, and it still doesn't catch all of the neutrons.

That being said, this is still a much lower production (and much safer) than Nuclear Fission, which we currently use now.

One mistake: fusion is not completely clean.
The products of the D-T reaction itself are Helium-4 and a neutron.
Helium-4 is inert and completely harmless, but the neutrons are a problem.
The neutrons are at extremely high energy, which means they move very fast, and when they hit other atoms they can fuse with them.
Unlike in a fission reaction, where the neutrons striking other atoms continues the chain reaction, most of the time these neutrons will simply create an isotope rather than splitting the atom. However, these isotopes tend to be radioactive, with fairly short half-lives (compared to fission byproducts. In human terms, it's still pretty long, being many years). Though their short-ish half-life means they will be safe far sooner than fission byproducts, it also means that they output very dangerous amounts of radiation. This process is known as "induced radioactivity".
These same problems exist in fission reactors, and the equipment used around them needs to be disposed of due to it, but in a fission reactor the neutrons are largely eaten by the control rods, and frankly you just store the irradiated equipment with the spent fuel anyway.

Also, there is a possible solution to the lack of Tritium on Earth: Lithium.
Lithium-6 and -7 are unstable when struck by a neutron, which causes them to fission into Hydrogen-3 and Helium-4 (and a neutron in the case of -7). Using Lithium as the coolant for the fusion reaction would expose it to the neutron flux of the reaction, which would turn some of it into Tritium, which can be separated later for use in the reaction again.

So, why can't we use fission as a stop-gap until we figure out fusion? Fission waste products can be used in breeder reactors or further reduced to more manageable elements using methods that can capture the released energy. Even if we simply store the waste (which is likely until we develop the aforementioned technologies) effective storage is mostly an issue because current regulations prevent large-scale storage projects, though also because of cost. Similarly, anti-nuclear sentiment has hampered development of 4th generation and on reactor designs. In the meantime, our 3rd generation designs are actually quite safe (Chernobyl was a 2nd gen and Fukushima was a special case), are far more green than any fossil fuels, and are far more reliable than any green sources. There are legitimate concerns regarding the use of nuclear power, but they're far easier to quantify than the slow build up of the various fossil fuel related humanitarian and environmental effects. I'd rather not let hysteria prevent us from using a valid energy source.

Nice video!
The point about tritium being rare is very true; with only ~50kg spread throughout the earth's atmosphere (created by cosmic rays interacting with free hydrogen and deuterium), and a commercial reactor requiring ~5kg per day, mining it would never work.
However, all D-T reactor designs breed their own tritium using fissile blankets of Lithium to capture the high-energy neutrons emitted by the reaction. The (now heated) liquid Lithium would then run through a heat exchanger to boil water, and an extractor to retrieve the precious tritium.
The point about producing no waste, unfortunately, is not true; those high-energy neutrons activate everything, making the walls of the reactor hideously radioactive (depending on design, the neutron flux is roughly 10x higher than for a fission reactor).
Helium 3 offers a more accessible fuel alternative but is still hard to get to.
Proton-boron fusion would be great, as no activating neutron radiation is produced and boron is plentiful (in comparison to H3 and Tritium), but the rate of the reaction is orders of magnitude less than for a D-T reaction, necessitating temperatures of billions of degrees for a viable reactor (not currently feasible, and unlikely to be), and far higher plasma pressures too.

That's a great video right there. Now, I have to point out a couple of flaws, since I work on a Tokamak and I know my field ;)
1.- ITER is not built yet! We expect the ITER facility to be finished around 2025.
2.- Helium-3 is not foreseen at all as a fusion fuel. While it is true that we make experiments with it to test its capabilities, harvesting He-3 would be much more difficult that obtaining Tritium.
3.- Tritium can be obtained from Lithium! In fact, modern devices such as ITER will have what is called a blanket, or in other words, the walls of the reactor will have an extra layer where neutrons are converted into Tritium by impinging onto a Lithium wall.
We work hard everyday to make this technology a yes in the future :) Thanks for the amazing video.
PD: If you speak Spanish, I have myself some videos about nuclear fusion and my daily work on the fusion reactor in this very channel, in case you want to check them out.

Yeah, Fusion Energy is great and all, but there are still some more drawbacks to it: Firstly, there will be nuclear waste from Fusion Reactors, which, while not as much and long lived as nuclear waste nowadays, still has to be contained somewhere. This is due to the fact that a reaction 3He+D may not result in radiation causing Neutrons, but there are still Deuterium atoms flying around in there and since Helium 3 and Deuterium need more energy to fuse, than D+D reactions, there will be D+D reactions, causing neutrons. The second flaw with Helium 3 is that it is located on the moon! That is 300.000km at least, plus the atmospheric ascend, plus sustaining a permanent moon base. That is more input cost than you'll get out of it. Especially because we will need at least 150 tons of 3He, if we want to power the whole world with it. And how much 3He is there per cubic meter of moon dust? I can not say for certain, but we would still need to sift through tons and tons of lunar regolith and only get a single kilogram. Last point: We can not even get a D+T reaction to deliver more input power than output over long time and 3He+D needs even more energy to fuse.
Tl; dr: Fusion Energy is great, but it has a lot more problems than shown in the video, sadly.

You claim that there's no danger, but that is a very premature statement. Especially because you're basing it on how fusion experiments are done now. But that's no guarantee that the final design will be the same. The Sun is using fusion as well and it's more or less self sufficient, not something you can easily 'turn off'. It's also the prime example of what we want: you don't have to put in any energy (or effort) in that process to make it 'work'. So wouldn't it be safe to conclude that if scientists are trying to reproduce this same very process that there is most definitely a high risk factor? It all depends on the eventual design, and since we don't know how that might look like we can't make statements that there is or isn't any danger. Not yet anyway.

personally, i think when it comes to fusion we need to give it a try. we have been trying to figure out a solution to our energy needs for years, and now we finally have a chance to solve that problem. I understand it would be extremely expensive but when the payoff is near unlimited energy with almost no environmental issues (and the only ones that there are are mostly negligible). the other potential issue other than Tritium Water is that while the fusion itself is clean mostly clean, ... well notice that i said mostly. deuterium has 1 neutron, tritium has 2 neutrons, deuterium and tritium fuse to form helium. but helium only has 2 neutrons, just like tritium, so where does that extra neutron go? it gets flung out of the plasma, unaffected by the super-cooled toridal electromagnets (btw im talking about the tokomak design, i dont know very much about the others so this may not be an issue with those) due to neutrons having no charge. I forgot what the magnets would be made of but lets say they are iron for simplicity's sake, when those neutrons fly out, they will likely merge with whatever they hit, now if they hit the magnets, to start with its no issue but the iron that makes up those magnets is eventually going to turn into something like iron-60, a radioactive isotope of iron, which will eventually decay until the magnet is no longer functional,  and then that magnet has to be replaced, and those magnets wouldnt come cheap. again its all about weighing up the pros vs the cons. personally im pro-fusion but thats just my opinion.

This is pretty dismissive of fission. Please don't bandwagon condemn fission as if its inherently worse than fusion.
Bottling a star also involves catching high energy neutrons in a blanket, which is also highly radioactive.
Bottling a star is very difficult and the fuel isn't common.
Fissioning common materials like thorium is much easier and the fuel is everywhere in space. If you want to travel the stars, you need to use the fuel that you can depend on being whereever you're headed. You also want your reactor to be easily maintainable. Trapping fusion in a magnetic field is very delicate work. Fissioning material that WANTS to fission is much less delicate.

That's the incredibly silly problem with humankind. We weight the environment, quality of life for everyone, and clean, unlimited power based on whether or not it is "economically viable".

Sometimes I think we don't deserve the chance to exist in this Universe that we have.

EDIT: to be specific, because people think "economically viable" = "physically viable", I'm talking about research and development of technologies in the right direction. Securing funds for such projects.

We don't know if fusion will pan out, but that should never be an "economical decision". Scientific progress and sustainability shouldn't be bound by economic policy, but by resource management.

Replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy is a massive project that's not considered "economically viable" right now, so we don't put nearly enough effort in that front. Dealing with climate change with "carbon tax" is a economy-minded way to deal with something that should supersede any economical concern. This shouldn't be how these things are handled.
